subQuestion.ans: There are only two possibilities.Case 1 :When point C is between the points A and B.We have,d(A, C) = 10; d(C, B) = 8Now, d(A, B) = d(A, C) + d(C, B)= 10 + 8∴ d(A, B) = 18Case 2 :When point B is between the points A and C.We have,d(A, C) = 10; d(C, B) = 8Now, d(A, C) = d(A, B) + d(B, C)So, d(A, B) = d(A, C) − d(B, C)= 10 − 8∴ d(A, B) = 2Therefore, When point B is between the points A and C then d(A, B) = 2∴ d(A, B) = 18 or d(A, B) = 2

questions.questionsTitle: On a number line, co-ordinates of P, Q, R are 3, -5 and 6 respectively. State with reason whether the following statement is true or false

subQuestion.ans: This statement isFalse.Explanation:The co-ordinates of points P, Q and R is 3, −5 and 6 respectively.We know that 3 > −5∴ d(P, Q) = 3 − (−5)∴ d(P, Q) = 3 + 5∴ d(P, Q) = 8We know that 6 > −5∴ d(Q, R) = 6 − (−5)∴ d(Q, R) = 6 + 5∴ d(Q, R) = 11We know that 6 > 3∴ d(P, R) = 6 − 3∴ d(P, R) = 3∴ d(P, Q) - d(P, R)= 8 - 3= 5But d(Q, R) = 11So, d(P, Q) - d(P, R) ≠ d(Q, R)

questions.questionsTitle: Co-ordinate of point P on a number line is - 7. Find the co-ordinates of points on the number line which are at a distance of 8 units from point P.

subQuestion.question: Co-ordinate of point P on a number line is - 7. Find the co-ordinates of points on the number line which are at a distance of 8 units from point P.
subQuestion.ans: Let point Q be at a distance of 8 units from P and on left side of PLet point R be at a distance of 8 units from P and on right side of P.(i)Let the co-ordinate of point Q be x.Co-ordinate of point P is -7.Since, point Q is to the left of point P.∴ -7 > x∴ d(P, Q) = -7 - x∴ 8 = -7 - x∴ x = -7 - 8∴ x = -15(ii)Let the co-ordinate of point R be y.Co-ordinate of point P is -7.Since, point R is to the right of point P.∴ y > -7∴ d(P, R) = 7 - (-7)∴ 8 = y + 7∴ 8 - 7 = 7∴ y = 1∴ The co-ordinates of the points at a distance of 8 units from P are -15 and 1.

questions.questionsTitle: If A-B-C and d(A, C) = 17, d(B, C) = 6.5 then d(A, B) = ?

subQuestion.ans: We have, d(A, C) = 17; d(B, C) = 6.5Now, d(A, C) = d(A, B) + d(B, C)  ...[A-B-C]So, d(A, B) = d(A, C) − d(B, C)∴ d(A, B) = 17 − 6.5∴ d(A, B) = 10.5

questions.questionsTitle: Co-ordinate of point A on a number line is 1. What are the co-ordinates of points on the number line which are at a distance of 7 units from A?

subQuestion.question: Co-ordinate of point A on a number line is 1. What are the co-ordinates of points on the number line which are at a distance of 7 units from A?
subQuestion.ans: The coordinate of point A is 1.Suppose point B is located at a distance of 7 units to the left of point A, whose coordinate is x.1 > x d(A, B) = 7∴ 7 = 1 – x∴ x = 1 – 7∴ x = - 6The coordinate of point B is – 6.Suppose point C is located at a distance of 7 units to the right of point A, whose coordinate is y.y > 1 d(A, C) = 7∴ 7 = y – 1∴ y = 7 + 1∴ y = 8The coordinate of point C is 8.The coordinates of points situated at a distance of 7 units from point A are - 6 and 8.

questions.questionsTitle: In the given figure, ∠ACD is an exterior angle of ΔABC. ∠B = 40°, ∠A = 70°. Find the measure of ∠ACD.

subQuestion.question: In the given figure, ∠ACD is an exterior angle of ΔABC. ∠B = 40°, ∠A = 70°. Find the measure of ∠ACD.
subQuestion.ans: ∠B = 40°, ∠A = 70°...(Given)In ΔABC,∠ACD = ∠A + ∠B    ...(Remote interior angle theorem)= 70° + 40°= 110°Hence, the measure of ∠ACD is 110°​.

questions.questionsTitle: In ΔPQR, ∠P = 70°, ∠Q = 65° then find ∠R.

subQuestion.question: In ΔPQR, ∠P = 70°, ∠Q = 65° then find ∠R.
subQuestion.ans: In ΔPQR,∠P + ∠Q + ∠R = 180°    ...(The sum of all angles of a triangle is 180°.)⇒ 70° + 65° + ∠R = 180°⇒ 135° + ∠R = 180°⇒ ∠R = 180° − 135°= 45°Hence, the measure of ∠ R is 45°.

questions.questionsTitle: The measures of angles of a triangle are x°, (x - 20)°, (x - 40)°. Find the measure of each angle.

subQuestion.question: The measures of angles of a triangle are x°, (x - 20)°, (x - 40)°. Find the measure of each angle.
subQuestion.ans: The measures of angles of a triangle are  x°, (x - 20)°, (x - 40)° respectively.∴ x° + (x - 20)° + (x - 40)° = 180°    ...(The sum of the angles of a triangle is 180°.)⇒ 3x - 60° = 180°⇒ 3x = 180° + 60°⇒ 3x = 240°⇒ x° = `(240°)/3`⇒ x° ​= 80°∴ (x - 20)° = (80° - 20)° = 60°∴ (x - 40)° = (80° - 40)° = 40°Hence, the measure of each angle is 80°, 60° and 40° respectively.

questions.questionsTitle: The measure of one of the angles of a triangle is twice the measure of its smallest angle and the measure of the other is thrice the measure of the smallest angle. Find the measures of the three angles.

subQuestion.question: The measure of one of the angles of a triangle is twice the measure of its smallest angle and the measure of the other is thrice the measure of the smallest angle. Find the measures of the three angles.
subQuestion.ans: Let us suppose the angles of a ΔPQR such that ∠P < ∠Q < ∠R.∴ ∠Q = 2∠P∴ ∠R = 3∠PNow, ∠P + ∠Q + ∠R = 180°      ...(The sum of the angles of a triangle is 180°.)⇒ ∠P + 2∠P + 3∠P = 180°⇒ 6∠P = 180°∠P = `(180°)/6`∴ ∠P = 30°∠Q = 2∠P = 2 × 30° = 60°∠R = 3∠P = 3 × 30° = 90°Hence, the measure of each angle is 30°, 60° and 90° respectively.

questions.questionsTitle: In the given figure, measures of some angles are given. Using the measures find the values of x, y, z.

subQuestion.question: In the given figure, measures of some angles are given. Using the measures find the values of x, y, z.
subQuestion.ans: ∠NEM + ∠NET = 180°   ...(Linear angle property)⇒ y + 100° = 180°⇒ y = 80°Also, ∠NME + ∠EMR = 180°  ...(Linear angle property)⇒ z + 140° = 180°⇒ z = 40°Now, In △NEM∠N + ∠E + ∠M = 180°   ...(Angle sum property)⇒ x + y + z = 180°⇒ x + 80° + 40° = 180°⇒ x + 120° = 180°⇒ x = 60°Hence, the values of x, y and z are 60°, 80° and 40° respectively.

questions.questionsTitle: In the given figure, line AB || line DE. Find the measures of ∠DRE and ∠ARE using given measures of some angles.

subQuestion.question: In the given figure, line AB || line DE. Find the measures of ∠DRE and ∠ARE using given measures of some angles.
subQuestion.ans: AB || DE and AD is a transversal line.∠BAR = ∠RDE = 70°      ...(Alternate angles)And line AD is their transversal∴ ∠BAD ≅ ∠EDA     ...(Alternate angles)∠BAD = 70°        ...(Given)∴ ∠EDA = 70°In other words ∠EDR = 70°     ...(A-R-D)∠ARE, ΔRDE exterior angle∴ ∠ARE = ∠EDR + ∠DER       ...(remote interior angle theorem)∴ ∠ARE = 70° + 40°∴ ∠ARE = 110°∠ARE + ∠DRE = 180°     ...(angles in linear pair)∴ 110° + ∠DRE = 180°∴ ∠DRE = 180° - 110°∴ ∠DRE = 70°

questions.questionsTitle: In Δ ABC, bisectors of ∠A and ∠B intersect at point O. If ∠C = 70°. Find the measure of ∠AOB.

subQuestion.question: In Δ ABC, bisectors of ∠A and ∠B intersect at point O. If ∠C = 70°. Find the measure of ∠AOB.
subQuestion.ans: ∠OAB ≅ ∠OAC   ...(Seg AO bisects ∠BAC)  ...(i)∠OBA ≅ ∠OBC    ...(Seg RO bisects ∠ABC)  ...(ii)In ΔABC,∠BAC + ∠ABC + ∠ACB = 180°     ...[Sum of the measures of the angles of a triangle is 180°]∴ ∠BAC + ∠ABC + 70° = 180°∴ ∠BAC + ∠ABC = 180° - 70°∴ ∠BAC + ∠ABC = 110°∴ `1/2 ("∠BAC") + 1/2 ("∠ABC")`= `1/2 xx 110°     ...["MuItiplying both sides by" 1/2]`∴ ∠OAB + ∠OBA = 55°    ...(iii)...[From (i) and (ii)]In ΔOAB,∠OAB + ∠OBA + ∠AOB = 180°   ...[Sum of the measures of the angles of a triangle is 180°]∴ 55° + ∠AOB = 180°      ...[From (iii)]∴ ∠AOB = 180° - 55°∴ ∠AOB = 125°

questions.questionsTitle: The length of hypotenuse of a right angled triangle is 15. Find the length of median of its hypotenuse.

subQuestion.question: The length of hypotenuse of a right angled triangle is 15. Find the length of median of its hypotenuse.
subQuestion.ans: In a right-angled triangle, the length of the median on its hypotenuse is half the length of the hypotenuse.Since the length of the hypotenuse = 15 unitWe know that,∴ Length of Median on its hypotenuse = `1/2xx"the length of the hypotenuse"`= `1/2xx15`= 7.5 unitsTherefore, the length of the median of its hypotenuse is 7.5 units.

questions.questionsTitle: In ΔPQR, ∠Q = 90°, PQ = 12, QR = 5 and QS is a median. Find l(QS).

subQuestion.question: In ΔPQR, ∠Q = 90°, PQ = 12, QR = 5 and QS is a median. Find l(QS).
subQuestion.ans: In △PQR, ∠Q = 90°      ...[Given]△PQR is a right angle triangle.∴ By Pythagoras theorem,∴ PR2= PQ2+ QR2⇒ PR2= 122+ 52⇒ PR2= 144 + 25⇒ PR2= 169⇒ PR = `sqrt169`⇒ PR= 13In △PQR,seg QS is the median on hypotenuse PR.∴ QS = `1/2`PR           ...[In a right angled triangle, the length of the median on the hypotenuse is half the length of the hypotenuse.]∴ QS = `1/2 × 13`∴ QS = 6.5 unitsHence, the length of QS is 6.5 units.

questions.questionsTitle: In the given figure, point G is the point of concurrence of the medians of Δ  PQR. If GT = 2.5, find the lengths of PG and PT.

subQuestion.question: In the given figure, point G is the point of concurrence of the medians of Δ  PQR. If GT = 2.5, find the lengths of PG and PT.
subQuestion.ans: GT = 2.5    ...(Given)The point of concurrence of medians of a triangle divides each median in the ratio 2 : 1.∴ `"PG"/"GT" = 2/1`∴ `"PG"/2.5 = 2/1`∴ PG = 2 × 2.5∴ PG = 5Now, PT = PG + GT= 5 + 2.5∴ PT = 7.5 unitsHence, the length of PG and PT is 5 and 7.5 units respectively.

questions.questionsTitle: In ΔFAN, ∠F = 80, ∠A = 40°. Find out the greatest and the smallest side of the triangle. State the reason.

subQuestion.question: In ΔFAN, ∠F = 80, ∠A = 40°. Find out the greatest and the smallest side of the triangle. State the reason.
subQuestion.ans: In ∆FAN,∠F + ∠A + ∠N = 180°     ...(sum of measures of angles of a triangle is 180°)⇒ 80° + 40° + ∠N = 180°⇒ 120° + ∠N = 180°⇒ ∠N = 180° − 120°= 60°Now, in △FAN, ∠F and ∠A are the largest and smallest angles.The side opposite to the largest angle is the greatest side and the side opposite to the smallest angle is the smallest side.Hence, the greatest and the smallest side of the triangle are AN and ​FN respectively.

questions.questionsTitle: Prove that an equilateral triangle is equiangular.

subQuestion.question: Prove that an equilateral triangle is equiangular.

questions.questionsTitle: In the given figure, in ΔABC, seg AD and seg BE are altitudes, and AE = BD. Prove that seg AD ≅ seg BE.

questions.questionsTitle: In Δ XYZ, XY = 4 cm, YZ = 6 cm, XZ = 5 cm, If ΔXYZ ~ Δ​PQR and PQ = 8 cm then find the lengths of remaining sides of ΔPQR.

subQuestion.question: In Δ XYZ, XY = 4 cm, YZ = 6 cm, XZ = 5 cm, If ΔXYZ ~ Δ​PQR and PQ = 8 cm then find the lengths of remaining sides of ΔPQR.
subQuestion.ans: Consider, ΔXYZ ~ ΔPQR`therefore ("XY")/("PQ") = ("YZ")/("QR") = ("XZ")/("PR")`     ...[Corresponding sides of similar triangles]⇒ `4/8 = 6/("QR") = 5/("PR")`⇒ `4/8 = 6/("QR")`⇒ `"QR" = (8 xx6)/4`⇒ QR = 12 cm⇒ `4/8 = 5/("PR")`⇒ PR = `(8 xx5)/4`⇒ PR = 10 cmHence, the lengths of remaining sides of ΔPQR are 12 and 10 cm.

subQuestion.ans: Given:In ΔPQR, PQ > PR and bisectors of ∠Q and ∠R intersect at S.To prove: SQ > SRProof:∠SQR = `1/2` ∠PQR        ...(i) ...[Ray QS bisects ∠PQR]∠SRQ = `1/2` ∠PRQ         ...(ii)  ...[Ray RS bisects ∠PRQ]In ∆PQR,PQ > PR         ...[Given]∴ ∠R > ∠Q        ....[Angle opposite to greater side is greater.]∴  `1/2 ("∠R") > 1/2 ("∠Q")       ...["Multiplying both sides by" 1/2]`∴ ∠SRQ > ∠SQR         ...(iii)   ...[From (i) and (ii)]In ∆SQR,∠SRQ > ∠SQR       ...[From (iii)]∴ SQ > SR        ...[Side opposite to greater angle is greater]

questions.questionsTitle: In the figure, point D and E are on side BC of ΔABC, such that BD = CE and AD = AE. Show that ΔABD ≅ ΔACE.

subQuestion.question: In the figure, point D and E are on side BC of ΔABC, such that BD = CE and AD = AE. Show that ΔABD ≅ ΔACE.
subQuestion.ans: ​In ∆ADE,seg AD = seg AE    ...[Given]∴ ∠ADE = ∠AED         ...(1) (Isosceles triangle theorem)Now,∠ADE + ∠ADB = 180°       ...(2)  [Angles in a linear pair]∠AED + ∠AEC = 180°       ...(3) [Angles in a linear pair]∴ ∠ADE + ∠ADB = ∠AED + ∠AEC      ...[From (2) and (3)]∴ ∠ADE + ∠ADB = ∠ADE + ∠AEC      ...[From (1)]⇒ ∠ADB = ∠AEC      ...(4)In ∆ABD and ∆ACE∠ADE = ∠AEC           ...[From (4)]seg BD ≅ seg CE       ...[Given]seg AD ≅ seg AE      ...[Given]By SAS test of congruency∴ ∆ABD ≅ ∆ACE      ...[SAS test]

questions.questionsTitle: In the given figure, bisector of ∠BAC intersects side BC at point D. Prove that AB > BD.

subQuestion.question: In the given figure, bisector of ∠BAC intersects side BC at point D. Prove that AB > BD.

questions.questionsTitle: In the given figure, seg AD ⊥ seg BC. seg AE is the bisector of ∠CAB and C - E - D. Prove that ∠DAE = `1/2` (∠C - ∠B)

subQuestion.question: In the given figure, seg AD ⊥ seg BC. seg AE is the bisector of ∠CAB and C - E - D. Prove that ∠DAE = `1/2` (∠C - ∠B)
subQuestion.ans: Given:seg AD ⊥ seg BCseg AE is the bisector of ∠CABTo prove:∠DAE = `1/2` (∠C – ∠B)Proof:∴ ∠CAE = `1/2` ∠A     ...(i) [seg AE is the bisector of ∠CAB]In ∆DAE,∠DAE + ∠ADE + ∠AED = 180°      ...[Sum of the measures of the angles of a triangle is 180°]∴ ∠DAE + 90° + ∠AED = 180°    ...[∵ AD ⊥ BC]∴ ∠DAE = 180° – 90° – ∠AED∴ ∠DAE = 90° – ∠AED    ...(ii)In ∆ACE,∴ ∠ACE + ∠CAE + ∠AEC = 180°      ...[Sum of the measures of the angles of a triangle is 180°]∠C + ∠A + ∠AED = 180°     ...[From (i) and C-D-E]∴ ∠AED = 180° – ∠C – `1/2` ∠A    …(iii)∴ ∠DAE = 90° – 180° – ∠C + `1/2` ∠A     ...[Substituting (iii) in (ii)]∴ ∠DAE = ∠C + `1/2` ∠A – 90°    ...(iv)In ∆ABC,∠A + ∠B + ∠C = 180°∴ `1/2 "∠A" + 1/2 "∠B" + 1/2 "∠C" = 90°`    ...[Dividing both side by 2]∴ `1/2 "∠A" = 90° - 1/2 "∠C" - 1/2 "∠B"`      ...(v)∴ ∠DAE = ∠C + `(90° 1/2 "∠C" - 1/2 "∠B") - 90°`   ...[Substituting (v) in (iv)]∴ ∠DAE = `"∠C" - 1/2  "∠C" - 1/2  "∠B"`= `1/2  "∠C" - 1/2  "∠B"`∴ ∠DAE = `1/2`(∠C - ∠B)

questions.questionsTitle: Diagonals of a parallelogram `square`WXYZ intersect each other at point O. If ∠XYZ = 135° then what is the measure of ∠XWZ and ∠YZW?If l(OY)= 5 cm then l(WY)= ?

subQuestion.ans: ∠XYZ = 135°`square`WXYZ is a parallelogram.∠XWZ = ∠XYZ∴ ∠XWZ = 135°    ...(i)ii.∠YZW + ∠XYZ = 180°    ...[Adjacent angles of a parallelogram are supplementary]∴ ∠YZW + 135° = 180°     ...[From (i)]∴ ∠YZW = 180° - 135°∴ ∠YZW = 45°iii.l(OY) = 5 cm    ...[Given]I(OY) = `1/2` I(WY)     ...[Diagonals of a parallelogram bisect each other]∴ I(WY) = 2 × l(OY)∴ I(WY) = 2 × 5∴ I(WY) = 10 cm

questions.questionsTitle: In a parallelogram `square`ABCD, If ∠A = (3x + 12)°, ∠B = (2x - 32)° then find the value of x and then find the measures of ∠C and ∠D.

subQuestion.question: In a parallelogram `square`ABCD, If ∠A = (3x + 12)°, ∠B = (2x - 32)° then find the value of x and then find the measures of ∠C and ∠D.
subQuestion.ans: Given:∠A = (3x + 12)˚ and ∠B = (2x - 32)˚Opposite angles of a parallelogram are equal.∴ ∠C = ∠A    ...(i)⇒ ∠C = (3x + 12)˚∠D = ∠B        …(ii)∠D = (2x - 32)˚In a quadrilateral, the sum of all the angles is equal to 360˚.∴ In `square`ABCD,∠A + ∠B + ∠C  + ∠D = 360˚∴ 3x + 12 + 2x - 32 + 3x + 12 + 2x - 32 = 360∴ 10x - 40 = 360∴ 10x = 360 + 40∴ 10x = 400∴ x = `400/10`∴ x = 40∴ ∠A = (3x + 12)˚⇒ ∠A = 3 × 40 +12⇒ ∠A = 120 + 12⇒ ∠A = 132˚∴ ∠C = 132˚        ...[From (i)]∴ ∠B = (2x - 32)˚⇒ ∠B = 2 × 40 - 32⇒ ∠B = 80 - 32⇒ ∠B = 48˚∴ ∠D = 48˚        ...[From (ii)]Hence, the measure of x is 40.Also, measures of ∠C and ∠D are 132˚ and 48˚ respectively.

questions.questionsTitle: Perimeter of a parallelogram is 150 cm. One of its sides is greater than the other side by 25 cm. Find the lengths of all sides.

subQuestion.question: Perimeter of a parallelogram is 150 cm. One of its sides is greater than the other side by 25 cm. Find the lengths of all sides.
subQuestion.ans: Let `square`ABCD be the parallelogram and the length of AD be x cm.One side is greater than the other by 25 cm.∴ AB = x + 25 cmAD = BC = x cmAB = DC = (x + 25) cm     ...[Opposite angles of a parallelogram]Perimeter of `square`ABCD = 150 cm     ...[Given]∴ AB + BC + DC + AD = 150∴ (x + 25) + x + (x + 25) + x = 150∴ 4x + 50 = 150∴ 4x = 150 – 50∴ 4x = 100∴ x = `100/4`∴ x = 25AD = BC = x = 25 cmAB = DC = x + 25 = 25 + 25 = 50 cm

questions.questionsTitle: If the ratio of measures of two adjacent angles of a parallelogram is 1 : 2, find the measures of all angles of the parallelogram.

subQuestion.question: If the ratio of measures of two adjacent angles of a parallelogram is 1 : 2, find the measures of all angles of the parallelogram.
subQuestion.ans: Let `square`ABCD be the parallelogram.The ratio of measures of two adjacent angles of a parallelogram is 1 : 2.Let the common multiple be x.∴ ∠A = x° and ∠B = 2x°∠A + ∠B = 180°     ...[Adjacent angles of a parallelogram are supplementary]∴ x + 2x = 180∴ 3x = 180∴ x = `180/3`∴ x = 60∠A = x° = 60°∠B = 2x°= 2 × 60° = 120°∠A = ∠C = 60°∠B = ∠D= 120°    ...[Opposite angles of a parallelogram]

subQuestion.question: In the given figure, G is the point of concurrence of medians of ΔDEF. Take point H on ray DG such that D-G-H and DG = GH, then prove that `square`GEHF is a parallelogram.
subQuestion.ans: Let, the median side drawn from point D intersects EF at point M.Point G is the concurrence point.The concurrence point divides each median in the ratio 2:1.∴ DG : GM = 2 : 1∴ `("DG")/("GM") = 2/1`∴ DG = 2GM      ...(i)∴ DG = GM + MH      ...(G-M-H)∴ 2GM = GM + MH    ...[from (i)]∴ 2GM – GM = MH∴ GM = MH      ...(ii)In `square`GEHF,Line GM ≅ Line MH      ...[From (ii)]Line EM ≅ Line MF       ...(Point M is the midpoint of line EF)A quadrilateral is a parallelogram if its diagonals bisect each other.`square`GEHF is a parallelogram.

questions.questionsTitle: Prove that quadrilateral formed by the intersection of angle bisectors of all angles of a parallelogram is a rectangle.

subQuestion.question: Prove that quadrilateral formed by the intersection of angle bisectors of all angles of a parallelogram is a rectangle.
subQuestion.ans: Given:`square`ABCD is a parallelogram.To prove:`square`PQRS is a rectangle.Proof:`square`ABCD is a parallelogram.

questions.questionsTitle: In the given figure, if points P, Q, R, S are on the sides of parallelogram such that AP = BQ = CR = DS then prove that `square`PQRS is a parallelogram.

subQuestion.question: In the given figure, if points P, Q, R, S are on the sides of parallelogram such that AP = BQ = CR = DS then prove that `square`PQRS is a parallelogram.
subQuestion.ans: Given:`square` ABCD is a parallelogram.AP = BQ = CR = DSTo prove:`square`PQRS is a parallelogram.Proof:AP = CR      ...(Given) ...(i)`square`ABCD is a parallelogram.AB = CD      ...(opposite sides of parallelogram)∴ AP + PB = CR + RD     ...[A-P-B, D-R-C]   ...(ii)∴ PB = RD       ...[From (i) and (ii)]     ...(iii)∠ABC ≅ ∠ADC    ...(Opposite angles of parallelogram)That is, ∠PBQ ≅ ∠RDS      ...(A-P-B, B-Q-C, C-R-D and A-S-D)    ...(iv)In ΔPBQ and ΔRDS,Seg PB ≅ Seg RD     ...[From (iii)]∠PBQ ≅ ∠RDS        ...[From (iv)]Seg BQ ≅ Seg SD       ...(Given)∴ ΔPBQ ≅ ΔRDS       ...[SAS test]Seg PQ ≅ Seg RS       ...(c.s.c.t) ...(v)Thus, we can prove that, ΔPAS ≅ ΔRCQ,∴ Seg PS ≅ Seg RQ       ...(vi)In `square`PQRS,Seg PQ ≅ Seg RS     ...[From (v)]Seg PS ≅ Seg RQ      ...[from (vi)]If the opposite sides of a quadrilateral are congruent, then it is a parallelogram.∴ `square`PQRS is a parallelogram.

subQuestion.question: Diagonals of a rectangle ABCD intersect at point O. If AC = 8 cm then find BO and if ∠CAD =35°  then find ∠ACB.
subQuestion.ans: AC = 8 cm     ...(i)  ...[Given]`square`ABCD is a rectangle    ...[Given]∴ BD = AC     ...[Diagonals of a rectangle are congruent]∴ BD = 8 cm      ...[From (i)]BO = `1/2` BD       ...[Diagonals of a rectangle bisect each other]∴ BO = `1/2` × 8∴ BO = 4 cmside AD || side BC and seg AC is their transversal.

questions.questionsTitle: Diagonals of a rhombus are 20 cm and 21 cm respectively, then find the side of rhombus and its perimeter.

subQuestion.question: Diagonals of a rhombus are 20 cm and 21 cm respectively, then find the side of rhombus and its perimeter.
subQuestion.ans: Let `square`ABCD be the rhombus.AC = 20 cm, BD = 21 cmAO = `1/2` AC        ...[Diagonals of a rhombus bisect each other]= `1/2 xx 20`= 10 cm       ...(i)BO = `1/2` BD         ...[Diagonals of a rhombus bisect each other]= `1/2 xx21`= `21/2`= 10.5 cm      ...(ii)In ∆AOB,∠AOB = 90°       ...[Diagonals of a rhombus are perpendicular to each other]By Pythagoras theorem,∴ AB2= AO2+ BO2∴ AB2= 102+ 10.52∴ AB2= 100 + 110.25∴ AB2= 210.25∴ AB = `sqrt(210.25)`∴ AB = 14.5 cmPerimeter of `square`ABCD = 4 × AB= 4 × 14.5= 58 cm

questions.questionsTitle: State with reason whether the following statement is 'true' or 'false'.

subQuestion.question: Every parallelogram is a rhombus.
subQuestion.ans: This statement isFalse.Reason:All the sides of a rhombus are congruent, while the opposite sides of a parallelogram are congruent.

questions.questionsTitle: State with reason whether the following statement is 'true' or 'false'.

subQuestion.question: Every rhombus is a rectangle.
subQuestion.ans: This statement isFalse.Reason:Opposite angles of a rhombus are congruent; however, all angles of a rectangle are congruent.

questions.questionsTitle: State with Reason Whether the Following Statement is 'True' Or 'False'.

subQuestion.question: Every rectangle is a parallelogram.
subQuestion.ans: This statement isTrue.Reason:All rectangle have the opposite pair of sides congruent and parallel and the diagonals bisect each other.

questions.questionsTitle: State with reason whether the following statement is 'true' or 'false'.

subQuestion.question: Every square is a rectangle.
subQuestion.ans: This statement isTrue.Reason:All sides of a square are congruent and its opposite sides are parallel; additionally, all its angles are congruent.All sides of a rectangle are parallel and its opposite sides are congruent; moreover, all its angles are congruent.

questions.questionsTitle: State with reason whether the following statement is 'true' or 'false'.

subQuestion.question: Every square is a rhombus.
subQuestion.ans: This statement isTrue.Reason:If all sides of any quadrilateral are congruent, then it is a rhombus.

questions.questionsTitle: State with reason whether the following statement is 'true' or 'false'.

subQuestion.question: Every parallelogram is a rectangle.
subQuestion.ans: This statement isFalse.Reason:If all angles of a quadrilateral are right angles, then it is a rectangle.

subQuestion.ans: Draw Seg BM ⊥ Seg AD such that A-M-D and Seg CN ⊥ AD so that A-N-DSeg BC || Seg AD       ...(Given)∴ BM = CN       ...(The distance between the lengths of the parallel sides of a parallelogram is equal.) ...(1)In ∆BMA and ∆CND,∠BMA = ∠CND = 90°Hypotenuse BA ≅ Hypotenuse CD   ...(Given)Seg BM ≅ Seg CN     ...[From (1)]∴ ∆BMA ≅ ∆CND      ...(Hypotenuse side test)∴ ∠BAM ≅ ∠CDN       ...(c.a.c.t)That is, ∠BAD ≅ ∠CDA        ...(A-M-D, A-N-D) ...(2)Seg BC || Seg AD         ...(Given)and side AB is their transversal.∴ ∠ABC + ∠BAD = 180°      ...(interior angle) ...(3)Seg BC || Seg AD    ...(Given)and side CD is their transversal.∴ ∠DCB + ∠CDA = 180°      ...(interior angle) ...(4)∴ ∠ABC + ∠BAD = ∠DCB + ∠CDA   ...[From (3) and (4)]∴ ∠ABC + ∠CDA = ∠DCB + ∠CDA   ...[From (2)]∴ ∠ABC = ∠DCB∴ ∠ABC ≅ ∠DCB

questions.questionsTitle: If the diagonal of a square is `12 sqrt 2` cm then the perimeter of square is ______.

subQuestion.question: If the diagonal of a square is `12 sqrt 2` cm then the perimeter of square is ______.
subQuestion.ans: If the diagonal of a square is `12 sqrt 2` cm then the perimeter of square is48 cm.Explanation:Let the diagonal be AC = `12 sqrt 2`Since it is a square so, all the angles are 90°.In ΔABC, we apply the Pythagoras theorem,AB2+ BC2= AC2⇒ AB2+ AB2= AC2(∵ `square`ABCD is a square.)⇒ 2 AB2= AC2⇒ 2 AB2= `(12 sqrt 2)^2`⇒ 2 AB2= 288⇒ AB2= 144⇒ AB = 12 cm∴ AB = BC = CD = AD = 12 cmPerimeter of `square`ABCD = 4AB= 4 × 12 cm= 48 cm

questions.questionsTitle: If opposite angles of a rhombus are (2x)° and (3x - 40)° then value of x is ______.

questions.questionsTitle: Ratio of two adjacent sides of a parallelogram is 3 : 4, and its perimeter is 112 cm. Find the length of its each side.

subQuestion.question: Ratio of two adjacent sides of a parallelogram is 3 : 4, and its perimeter is 112 cm. Find the length of its each side.
subQuestion.ans: Let `square`ABCD be a parallelogram.AB : BC = 3 : 4If AB = 3x cmSo, BC = 4x cm        ...(x is the common multiple.)∴ CD = AB = 3x cm and AD = BC = 4x cm      ...(opposite sides of parallelogram)Perimeter of `square`ABCD = 112 cm∴ AB + BC + CD + AD = 112∴ 3x + 4x + 3x + 4x = 112∴ 14x = 112∴ x = `112/14`∴ x = 8∴ CD = AB = 3x = 3 × 8 = 24 cm∴ AD = BC = 4x = 4 × 8 = 32 cm

questions.questionsTitle: Diagonals PR and QS of a rhombus PQRS are 20 cm and 48 cm respectively. Find the length of side PQ.

subQuestion.question: Diagonals PR and QS of a rhombus PQRS are 20 cm and 48 cm respectively. Find the length of side PQ.
subQuestion.ans: Diagonals of a rhombus bisect each other at right angles.PR = 20 cm, QS = 48 cm⇒ `"PO" = 1/2 "PR"`= `1/2 xx 20`= 10 cmSimilarly, QS = 48 cm⇒ `"QO" = 1/2 "SQ"`= `1/2 xx 48`= 24 cmIn ΔPOQ, applying Pythagoras theorem,OQ2+ QP2= PQ2⇒ 242+ 102= PQ2⇒ PQ2= 576 + 100⇒ PQ2= 676⇒ PQ = 26 cm

questions.questionsTitle: Diagonals of a rectangle PQRS are intersecting in point M. If ∠QMR = 50° find the measure of ∠MPS.

subQuestion.question: Diagonals of a rectangle PQRS are intersecting in point M. If ∠QMR = 50° find the measure of ∠MPS.
subQuestion.ans: `square`PQRS is a rectangle.∴ PM = `1/2` PR     …(i)MS = `1/2` QS       …(ii) ...(Diagonals of a rectangle bisect each other)Also, PR = QS      …(iii) ...(Diagonals of a rectangle are congruent)∴ PM = MS      …(iv)   ...[From (i), (ii) and (iii)]In ∆PMS,PM = MS      ...[From (iv)]∴ ∠MSP = ∠MPS = x°       ...(v) ...(Isosceles triangle theorem)∠PMS = ∠QMR = 50°      ...(vi) ...(Vertically opposite angles)In ∆MPS,∠PMS + ∠MPS + ∠MSP = 180°      ...(The sum of the measures of the three angles of a triangle is 180°.)∴ 50° + x + x = 180°      ...[From (v) and (vi)]∴ 50° + 2x = 180°∴ 2x = 180° - 50°∴ 2x = 130°∴ x = `(130°)/2`∴ x = 65°∴ ∠MPS = 65°       ...[From (v)]

questions.questionsTitle: Length, breadth and height of a cuboid shape box of medicine is 20 cm, 12 cm and 10 cm respectively. Find the surface area of vertical faces and total surface area of this box.

subQuestion.question: Length, breadth and height of a cuboid shape box of medicine is 20 cm, 12 cm and 10 cm respectively. Find the surface area of vertical faces and total surface area of this box.
subQuestion.ans: Length of the box, l = 20 cmBreadth of the box, b = 12 cmHeight of the box, h = 10 cm∴ The surface area of the vertical faces of the box= 2(l + b) × h= 2(20 + 12) × 10= 2 × 32 × 10= 640 cm2Also,The total surface area of the box= 2(lb + bh + hl)= 2(20 × 12 + 12 × 10 + 10 × 20)= 2(240 + 120 + 200)= 2 × 560= 1120 cm2Thus, the surface area of the vertical faces and the total surface area of the box are 640 cm2and 1120 cm2, respectively.

questions.questionsTitle: Total surface area of a box of cuboid shape is 500 sq. unit. Its breadth and height is 6 unit and 5 unit respectively. What is the length of that box ?

subQuestion.question: Total surface area of a box of cuboid shape is 500 sq. unit. Its breadth and height is 6 unit and 5 unit respectively. What is the length of that box ?
subQuestion.ans: Let the length of the box be l unit.Breadth of the box, b = 6 unitsHeight of the box, h = 5 unitsTotal surface area of the box = 500 square units∴ 2(lb+ bh + hl) = 500 square units⇒ l x 6 + 6 x 5 + 5 x l = `500/2`⇒ 6l + 30 + 5l = 250⇒ 11 l = 250 - 30⇒ 11 l = 220⇒ l = `220/11`⇒ l = 20 unitsThus, the length of the box is 20 units.

questions.questionsTitle: Side of a cube is 4.5 cm. Find the surface area of all vertical faces and total surface area of the cube.

subQuestion.question: Side of a cube is 4.5 cm. Find the surface area of all vertical faces and total surface area of the cube.
subQuestion.ans: Side of the cube, l = 4.5 cm∴ Surface area of all vertical faces of the cube = 4l2= 4 × (4.5 cm)2= 4 × 20.25 cm2= 81 cm2Also,Total surface area of the cube = 6l2= 6 × (4.5 cm)2= 6 × 20.25 cm2= 121.50 cm2Thus, the surface area of all the vertical faces and total surface area of the cube is 81 cm2and 121.50 cm2, respectively.

questions.questionsTitle: Total surface area of a cube is 5400 sq. cm. Find the surface area of all vertical faces of the cube.

subQuestion.question: Total surface area of a cube is 5400 sq. cm. Find the surface area of all vertical faces of the cube.
subQuestion.ans: Let the edge of the cube be l cm.Total surface area of the cube = 5400 cm2∴ 6l2= 5400⇒ l2= `5400/6` = 900⇒ l = `sqrt900` = 30 cm∴ Surface area of all vertical faces of the cube = 4l2= 4 × (30 cm)2= 4 × 900 cm2= 3600 cm2Thus, the surface area of all vertical faces of the cube is 3600 cm2.

questions.questionsTitle: Volume of a cuboid is 34.50 cubic metre. Breadth and height of the cuboid is 1.5m and 1.15m respectively. Find its length.

subQuestion.question: Volume of a cuboid is 34.50 cubic metre. Breadth and height of the cuboid is 1.5m and 1.15m respectively. Find its length.
subQuestion.ans: Let the length of the cuboid be l m.Breadth of the cuboid, b = 1.5 mHeight of the cuboid, h = 1.15 mVolume of the cuboid = 34.50 m3∴ l × b × h = 34.50 m3⇒ l × 1.5 × 1.15 = 34.50⇒ l = `34.50/[1.5 xx 1.15]`⇒ l = `(3450 × 10 × 100)/(100 × 15 × 115)`= 20 mThus, the length of the cuboid is 20 m.

questions.questionsTitle: What will be the volume of a cube having length of edge 7.5 cm?

questions.questionsTitle: Radius of base of a cylinder is 20 cm and its height is 13 cm, find its curved surface area and total surface area. (π = 3.14)

subQuestion.question: Radius of base of a cylinder is 20 cm and its height is 13 cm, find its curved surface area and total surface area. (π = 3.14)
subQuestion.ans: Radius of the cylinder, r = 20 cmHeight of the cylinder, h = 13 cm∴ Curved surface area of the cylinder = 2πrh= 2 × 3.14 × 20 × 13= 1632.80 cm2Also,Total surface area of the cylinder = 2πr (r + h)= 2 × 3.14 × 20 × (20 + 13)= 2 × 3.14 × 20 × 33= 4144.80 cm2Thus, the curved surface area and the total surface area of the cylinder is 1632.80 cm2and 4144.80 cm2, respectively.

questions.questionsTitle: Curved surface area of a cylinder is 1980 cm2and radius of its base is 15 cm. Find the height of the cylinder. (π = `22/7`)

subQuestion.question: Curved surface area of a cylinder is 1980 cm2and radius of its base is 15 cm. Find the height of the cylinder. (π = `22/7`)
subQuestion.ans: Let the height of the cylinder be h cm.Radius of the cylinder, r = 15 cmCurved surface area of the cylinder = 1980 cm2∴ 2πrh = 1980 cm2⇒ `2 xx 22/7 xx 15 xx "h" = 1980`⇒ `"h" = [ 1980 xx 7]/(2 × 22 × 15)`⇒ `"h" = [cancel(1980)^3 xx 7]/cancel(660)_1`⇒ h = 3 × 7⇒ h = 21 cmThus, the height of the cylinder is 21 cm.

questions.questionsTitle: Perpendicular height of a cone is 12 cm and its slant height is 13 cm. Find the radius of the base of the cone.

subQuestion.question: Perpendicular height of a cone is 12 cm and its slant height is 13 cm. Find the radius of the base of the cone.
subQuestion.ans: Let the radius of the base of the cone be r cm.Height of the cone, h = 12 cmSlant height of the cone, l = 13 cmNow,r2+ h2= l2⇒ r2+ (12)2=(13)2⇒ r2+ 144 = 169⇒ r2= 169 − 144 = 25⇒ r = `sqrt 25` = 5cmThus, the radius of the base of the cone is 5 cm.

questions.questionsTitle: Find the volume of a cone, if its total surface area is 7128 sq. cm and radius of base is 28 cm. `(π = 22/7)`

subQuestion.question: Find the volume of a cone, if its total surface area is 7128 sq. cm and radius of base is 28 cm. `(π = 22/7)`
subQuestion.ans: Let the perpendicular height and the slant height of the cone be h cm and l cm, respectively.Radius of the base of cone, r = 28 cmTotal surface area of the cone = 7128 cm2∴ πr(r + l) = 7128 cm2⇒ `22/7 xx 28 xx (28 + "l") = 7128`⇒ `7128 xx 7/22 xx 1/28 = l + 28`⇒ 81 − 28 = l⇒ l = 53 cmNow,l2= r2+ h2⇒ (53)2= (28)2+ h2⇒ h2= 2809 − 784 = 2025⇒ h = `sqrt 2025`⇒ h = 45 cm∴ Volume of the cone = `1/3`πr2h= `1/3 xx 22/7 xx (28)^2 xx 45`= 36960 cm3Thus, the volume of the cone is 36960 cm3.

questions.questionsTitle: Curved surface area of a cone is 251.2 cm2and radius of its base is 8 cm. Find its slant height and perpendicular height. (π = 3.14)

subQuestion.question: Curved surface area of a cone is 251.2 cm2and radius of its base is 8 cm. Find its slant height and perpendicular height. (π = 3.14)
subQuestion.ans: Let the perpendicular height and slant height of the cone be h cm and l cm, respectively.Radius of the base of cone, r = 8 cmCurved surface area of the cone = 251.2 cm2∴ πrl = 251.2 cm2⇒ 3.14 x 8 x l = 251.2⇒ l = `251.2/25.12` = 10 cmNow,r2+ h2= l2⇒ (8)2+ h2= (10)2⇒ 64 + h2= 100⇒ h2= 100 - 64 = 36⇒ h = `sqrt36` = 6 cmThus, the slant height and perpendicular height of the cone are 10 cm and 6 cm, respectively.

questions.questionsTitle: What will be the cost of making a closed cone of tin sheet having radius of base 6 m and slant height 8 m if the rate of making is Rs.10 per sq.m? `(π = 22/7)`

subQuestion.question: What will be the cost of making a closed cone of tin sheet having radius of base 6 m and slant height 8 m if the rate of making is Rs.10 per sq.m? `(π = 22/7)`
subQuestion.ans: Radius of the base of cone, r = 6 mSlant height of the cone, l = 8 m∴ Total surface area of the cone = πr(r + l)= `22/7 xx 6 xx (6 + 8)`= `22/7 xx 6 xx 14`= 264 m2Rate of making the cone of tin sheet = Rs 10/m2∴ Total cost of making the cone of tin sheet= Total surface area of the cone × Rate of making the cone of tin sheet= 264 × 10= Rs 2640Thus, the cost of making the cone of tin sheet is Rs 2640.

questions.questionsTitle: Surface area of a cone is 188.4 sq.cm and its slant height is 10 cm. Find its perpendicular height (π = 3.14).

subQuestion.question: Surface area of a cone is 188.4 sq.cm and its slant height is 10 cm. Find its perpendicular height (π = 3.14).
subQuestion.ans: Let the radius of the base and perpendicular height of the cone be r cm and h cm, respectively.Slant height of the cone, l = 10 cmSurface area of the cone = 188.4 cm2∴ πrl = 188.4 cm2⇒ 3.14 × r x 10 = 188.4⇒ r = `[188.4]/[3.14 xx 10]` = 6 cmNow,r2+  h2= l2⇒ (6)2+ h2= (10)2⇒ 36 + h2= 100⇒ h2= 100 − 36 = 64⇒  h= `sqrt 64` = 8 cm.Thus, the perpendicular height of the cone is 8 cm.

questions.questionsTitle: Volume of a cone is 1232 cm3and its height is 24 cm. Find the surface area of the cone. `( π = 22/7)`

subQuestion.question: Volume of a cone is 1232 cm3and its height is 24 cm. Find the surface area of the cone. `( π = 22/7)`
subQuestion.ans: Let the radius of the base and slant height of the cone be r cm and lcm, respectively.Height of the cone, h = 24 cmVolume of the cone = 1232 cm3∴ `1/3`πr2h = 1232 cm3∴ `1232 = 1/3 × 22/7 × r^2 × 24`⇒ `(1232xx3xx7)/(22xx24) =  r^2    ...("Multiplying both sides by"  3xx7/22xx1/24)`⇒ r2= 49⇒ r = `sqrt(49)`⇒ r = 7 cmNow,l2= r2+ h2⇒ l2= (7)2+ (24)2⇒ l2= 49 + 576⇒ l2= 625⇒ l = `sqrt 625`⇒ l = 25 cm∴ Curved Surface area of the cone = πrl= `22/7 xx 7 xx 25`= 550 cm2Thus, the surface area of the cone is approximately 550 cm2.

questions.questionsTitle: The curved surface area of a cone is 2200 sq.cm and its slant height is 50 cm. Find the total surface area of cone. `(π = 22/7)`

subQuestion.question: The curved surface area of a cone is 2200 sq.cm and its slant height is 50 cm. Find the total surface area of cone. `(π = 22/7)`
subQuestion.ans: Let the radius of the base of the cone be r cm.Slant height of the cone, l = 50 cmCurved surface area of the cone = 2200 cm2∴ πrl = 2200 cm2⇒ `22/7 xx r xx 50` = 2200⇒ r = `[2200 xx 7]/[22 xx 50]`⇒ r = 14 cm∴ Total surface of the cone = πr(r + l)= `22/7 xx 14 xx (14 + 50)`= `22/7 xx 14 xx 64`= 2816 cm2Thus, the total surface area of the cone is 2816 cm2.

questions.questionsTitle: There are 25 persons in a tent which is conical in shape. Every person needs an area of 4 sq.m. of the ground inside the tent. If height of the tent is 18 m, find the volume of the tent.

questions.questionsTitle: Ray PQ and ray PR are perpendicular to each other. Points B and A are in the interior and exterior of ∠QPR respectively. Ray PB and ray PA are perpendicular to each other. Draw a figure showing all these rays and write -A pair of complementary anglesA pair of supplementary angles.A pair of congruent angles.

subQuestion.question: Ray PQ and ray PR are perpendicular to each other. Points B and A are in the interior and exterior of ∠QPR respectively. Ray PB and ray PA are perpendicular to each other. Draw a figure showing all these rays and write -
subQuestion.ans: Since ray PQ ⊥ ray PR, then m∠QPR = 90∘and ray PA ⊥ ray PB, then m∠APB = 90∘.(i)Two angles, sum of whose measures is 90∘, are called complementary angles.Here, m∠QPR = 90∘⇒ m∠BPQ + m∠BPR = 90∘∴ ∠BPQ and ∠BPR are complementary angles.(ii)Two angles, sum of whose measures is 180∘, are called supplementary angles.⇒ m∠APB + m∠QPR= 90∘+ 90∘= 180∘∴ ∠APB and ∠QPR are supplementary angles.(iii)Angles with the same measures are called congruent angles.Here, m∠QPR = m∠APB = 90∘∴ ∠APB and ∠QPR are congruent angles.

questions.questionsTitle: Line AB || line CD || line EF and line QP is their transversal. If y : z = 3 : 7 then find the measure of ∠x.

subQuestion.question: Line AB || line CD || line EF and line QP is their transversal. If y : z = 3 : 7 then find the measure of ∠x.
subQuestion.ans: line AB || line EF      ...(Given)And the line QP is their transversal.∴ ∠x ≅ ∠z     ...(Alternate angles)∠y : ∠z = 3 : 7    ...(Given)∴ ∠y = ∠x = 3 : 7Let m be a common multiple of the ratio 3 : 7.∴ ∠y = 3m, ∠x = 7mline AB || line CD     ...(Given)And the line QP is their transversal.∴ ∠x + ∠y = 180°    ...(interior angle theorem)∴ 7m + 3m = 180°∴ 10m = 180°∴ m = `(180°)/10`∴ m = 18°∠x = 7m∴ ∠x = 7 × 18°∴ ∠x = 126°

questions.questionsTitle: In the given figure, if line q || line r, line p is their transversal and if a = 80° find the values of f and g.

subQuestion.question: In the given figure, if line q || line r, line p is their transversal and if a = 80° find the values of f and g.
subQuestion.ans: Since line q || line r and line p is their transversal, then∠g = ∠a     ...(Alternate exterior angles)⇒ ∠g = 80∘Since ∠g and ∠f are forming a linear pair, then∠f + ∠g = 180∘...(Angles in a linear pair are supplementary)⇒ ∠f = 180∘− ∠g⇒ ∠f = 180∘− 80∘⇒ ∠f = 100∘Hence, the values of f and g are 100∘and 80∘respectively.

questions.questionsTitle: In the given figure, if line AB || line CF and line BC || line ED then prove that ∠ABC = ∠FDE.

subQuestion.question: In the given figure, if line AB || line CF and line BC || line ED then prove that ∠ABC = ∠FDE.
subQuestion.ans: Let us mark the points M and N on line BC and point G on line ED.Since line AB || line PF (or line CF) and line MN is their transversal,∠PCN = ∠ABC      ...(Corresponding angles)...(1)Since line MN || line EG and line PF is their transversal, then∠PCN = ∠CDG       ...(Corresponding angles)...(2)Since EG and PF are straight lines intersecting at D, then∠CDG = ∠FDE       ...(Vertically opposite angles) ...(3)∴ from (2) and (3), we get∠PCN = ∠FDE    ...(4)∴ from (1) and (4), we get∠ABC = ∠FDE

questions.questionsTitle: Distance of chord AB from the centre of a circle is 8 cm. Length of the chord AB is 12 cm. Find the diameter of the circle.

subQuestion.question: Distance of chord AB from the centre of a circle is 8 cm. Length of the chord AB is 12 cm. Find the diameter of the circle.
subQuestion.ans: Let point O be the center of the circle.seg OC ⊥ chord AB such that, A-C-BAC = `1/2` AB          ...(The perpendicular drawn from the center of the circle to the chord bisects the chord.)∴ AC = `1/2 xx 12`∴ AC = 6 cmDraw line OA.In ∆OCA, From Pythagoras theorem,OA2= OC2+ AC2∴ OA2= 82+ 62∴ OA2= 64 + 36∴ OA2= 100∴ OA = `sqrt(100)`∴ OA = 10 cm∴ Diameter of circle = `2 xx10`∴ Diameter of circle = 20 cm

questions.questionsTitle: Diameter of a circle is 26 cm and length of a chord of the circle is 24 cm. Find the distance of the chord from the centre.

subQuestion.question: Diameter of a circle is 26 cm and length of a chord of the circle is 24 cm. Find the distance of the chord from the centre.
subQuestion.ans: Let O be the center of the circle and seg PQ is its chord.seg OR ⊥ chord PQ such that, P-R-QPQ = 24 cmdiameter of circle = 26 cmradius = `1/2 xx26`= 13 cmDraw line OP.∴ OP = 13 cm∴ PR = `1/2` PQ      ...(Perpendicular drawn from the center of a circle to the chord bisects the chord.)∴ PR = `1/2 xx 24`∴ PR = 12 cmIn ∆ORP, From Pythagoras theorem,OP2= OR2+ PR2∴ 132= OR2+ 122∴ 169 = OR2– 144∴ OR2= 169 – 144∴ OR2= 25∴ OR = `sqrt(25)`∴ OR = 5 cm∴ The distance of the chord from the centre of the circle is 5 cm.

questions.questionsTitle: Radius of a circle is 34 cm and the distance of the chord from the centre is 30 cm, find the length of the chord.

subQuestion.question: Radius of a circle is 34 cm and the distance of the chord from the centre is 30 cm, find the length of the chord.
subQuestion.ans: Let O be the center of the circle and seg AB is its chord.seg OC ⊥ chord AB such that, A-C-BOA = 34 cmOC = 30 cmIn ∆OCA, From Pythagoras theorem,OA2= OC2+ AC2∴ 342= 302+ AC2∴ 1156 = 900 + AC2∴ AC2= 1156 – 900∴ AC2= 256∴ AC = `sqrt(256)`∴ AC = 16 cm∴ AC = `1/2` AB      ...(The perpendicular drawn from the center of the circle to the chord bisects the chord.)∴ 16 = `1/2` AB∴ AB = `16 xx 2`∴ AB = 32 cm

questions.questionsTitle: Radius of a circle with centre O is 41 units. Length of a chord PQ is 80 units, find the distance of the chord from the centre of the circle.

subQuestion.question: Radius of a circle with centre O is 41 units. Length of a chord PQ is 80 units, find the distance of the chord from the centre of the circle.
subQuestion.ans: Let O be the center of the circle and seg PQ is its chord.seg OR ⊥ chord PQ such that, P-R-QPQ = 80 unitOP = 41 unitPR = `1/2` PQ       ...(Perpendicular drawn from the center of a circle to the chord bisects the chord.)∴ PR = `1/2 xx 80`∴ PR = 40 unitIn ∆ORP, From Pythagoras theorem,OP2= OR2+ PR2∴ 412= OR2+ 402∴ 1681 = OR2+ 1600∴ OR2= 1681 – 1600∴ OR2= 81∴ OR = `sqrt(81)`∴ OR = 9 unit

questions.questionsTitle: In the given figure, centre of two circles is O. Chord AB of bigger circle intersects the smaller circle in points P and Q. Show that AP = BQ.

subQuestion.question: In the given figure, centre of two circles is O. Chord AB of bigger circle intersects the smaller circle in points P and Q. Show that AP = BQ.
subQuestion.ans: Given:Two concentric circles having centre O.To prove:AP = BQConstruction:Draw the line OM ⊥ chord AB such that, A-M-BProof:With respect to the small circle, seg OM ⊥ chord PQ∴ PM = MQ       ...(i) ...(The perpendicular drawn from the center of the circle to the chord bisects the chord.)Similarly, with respect to the great circle, seg OM ⊥ chord AB∴ AM = MB       ...(ii)AM = AP + PM      ...(A-P-M) ...(iii)MB = MQ + QB       ...(M-Q-B) ...(iv)∴ AP + PM = MQ + QB      ...[from (ii), (iii) and (iv)] ...(v)∴ AP = BQ      ...[from (i) and (v)]

questions.questionsTitle: Radius of circle is 10 cm. There are two chords of length 16 cm each. What will be the distance of these chords from the centre of the circle?

subQuestion.question: Radius of circle is 10 cm. There are two chords of length 16 cm each. What will be the distance of these chords from the centre of the circle?
subQuestion.ans: Let, O be the center of the circle and seg AB and seg CD are its congruent chords.seg OM ⊥ seg AB such that, A-M-B and seg ON ⊥ seg CD such that, C-N-D.OB = OD = 10 cm      ...(Radius of the circle is 10 cm.)AB = CD = 16 cm      …(Given)∴ MB = `1/2` AB       ...(The perpendicular drawn from the center of the circle to the chord bisects the chord.)∴ MB = `1/2 xx 16`∴ MB = 8 cmIn ∆OMB, by Pythagoras theorem,OB2= OM2+ MB2∴ 102= OM2+ 82∴ OM2= 100 – 64∴ OM2= 36Taking the square root on both sides,∴ OM = `sqrt(36)`∴ OM = 6 cm∴ ON = OM       ...(Congruent chords of a circle are the same distance from the centre.)∴ ON = 6 cm

questions.questionsTitle: In a circle with radius 13 cm, two equal chords are at a distance of 5 cm from the centre. Find the lengths of the chords.

subQuestion.question: In a circle with radius 13 cm, two equal chords are at a distance of 5 cm from the centre. Find the lengths of the chords.
subQuestion.ans: Let, O be the center of the circle and seg AB and seg CD are equal-length chords of the circle.seg OE ⊥ seg AB such that, A-E-B and seg OF ⊥ seg CD such that, C-F-D.OA = OD = 13 cm      ...(Radius of the circle is 13 cm.)In ∆AEO, by Pythagoras theorem,OA2= OE2+ EA2∴ 132= 52+ EA2∴ EA2= 169 – 25∴ EA2= 144∴ EA = `sqrt(144)`∴ EA = 12 cm∴ EA = `1/2` BA       ...(The perpendicular drawn from the center of the circle to the chord bisects the chord.)∴ 12 = `1/2` BA∴ BA = `12 xx 2`∴ BA = 24 cmchord AB ≅ chord CD∴ CD = 24 cm

questions.questionsTitle: Seg PM and seg PN are congruent chords of a circle with centre C. Show that the ray PC is the bisector of ∠NPM.

subQuestion.question: Seg PM and seg PN are congruent chords of a circle with centre C. Show that the ray PC is the bisector of ∠NPM.
subQuestion.ans: Given:Point C is the centre of the circle.chord PM ≅ chord PNTo prove:Ray PC is the bisector of ∠NPM.Proof:Draw seg CM and seg CN.In ∆CPM and ∆CPN,seg PM ≅ seg PN      ...(Given)seg PC ≅ seg PC      ...(Common side)seg CM ≅ seg CN      ...(radii of the same circle)∴ ∆CPM ≅ ∆CPN      ...(By SSS congruency)∴ ∠CPM ≅ ∠CPN      ...(c.a.c.t.)∴ Ray PC is the bisector of ∠NPM.

subQuestion.question: If cos θ = `15/17` then find sin θ.
subQuestion.ans: sin2θ + cos2θ = 1⇒ sin2θ + `(15/17)^2 = 1              ...( cos θ = 15/17)`⇒ sin2θ + `225/289` = 1⇒ sin2θ = `1 - 225/289`⇒ sin2θ = `(289 - 225)/289`⇒ sin2θ = `64/289`⇒ sin θ = `sqrt (64/289)`       ...(Taking square root of both sides)⇒ sin θ = `8/17`Thus, the value of sin θ is `8/17`.

questions.questionsTitle: In right angled ΔTSU, TS = 5, ∠S = 90°, SU = 12 then find sin T, cos T, tan T. Similarly find sin U, cos U, tan U.

subQuestion.question: In right angled ΔTSU, TS = 5, ∠S = 90°, SU = 12 then find sin T, cos T, tan T. Similarly find sin U, cos U, tan U.
subQuestion.ans: In right ∆TSU,TU2= SU2+ TS2...(Pythagoras theorem)⇒ TU2= 122+ 52⇒ TU2= 144 + 25⇒ TU2= 169⇒ TU = 13Now,sin T = `("∠T"  "opposite side")/("Hypotenuse") = "SU"/"TU" = 12/13`cos T = `("∠T"  "adjacent side")/("Hypotenuse") = "TS"/"TU" = 5/13`tan T = `("∠T"  "opposite side")/("∠T"  "adjacent side") = "SU"/"TS"  = 12/5`Also,sin U = `("∠U"  "opposite side")/("Hypotenuse") = "TS"/"TU" = 5/13`cos U = `("∠U"  "adjacent side")/("Hypotenuse") = "SU"/"TU" = 12/13`tan U = `("∠U"  "opposite side")/("∠U"  "adjacent side") = "TS"/"SU" = 5/12`

questions.questionsTitle: In right angled ΔYXZ, ∠X = 90°, XZ = 8 cm, YZ = 17 cm, find sin Y, cos Y, tan Y, sin Z, cos Z, tan Z.

subQuestion.question: In right angled ΔYXZ, ∠X = 90°, XZ = 8 cm, YZ = 17 cm, find sin Y, cos Y, tan Y, sin Z, cos Z, tan Z.
subQuestion.ans: In right ∆YXZ,YZ2= XZ2+ XY2...(Pythagoras theorem)⇒ XY2= YZ2− XZ2⇒ XY2= 172− 82⇒ XY2= 289 − 64⇒ XY2= 225⇒ XY2= 152∴  XY = 15 cmNow,sin Y = `("∠Y"  "opposite side")/"Hypotenuse" =  "XZ"/"YZ" = 8/17`cos Y = `("∠Y"  "adjacent side")/"Hypotenuse" = "XY"/"YZ" = 15/17`tan Y = `("∠Y"  "opposite side")/("∠Y"  "adjacent side") = "XZ"/"XY" = 8/15`Also,sin Z = `("∠Z"  "opposite side")/"Hypotenuse" = "XY"/"YZ" = 15/17`cos Z = `("∠Z"  "adjacent side")/"Hypotenuse" = "XZ"/"YZ" = 8/17`tan Z = `("∠Z"  "opposite side")/("∠Z"  "adjacent side") = "XY"/"XZ" = 15/8`

questions.questionsTitle: In right angled ΔLMN, if ∠N =θ, ∠M = 90, cos θ =`24/25`, find sin θ and tan θ Similarly, find (sin2θ) and (cos2θ).

subQuestion.question: In right angled ΔLMN, if ∠N =θ, ∠M = 90, cos θ =`24/25`, find sin θ and tan θ Similarly, find (sin2θ) and (cos2θ).
subQuestion.ans: In right ∆LMN, ∠N = θcos θ = `24/25`⇒ `"MN"/"LN" = 24/25`Let MN = 24k and LN = 25kUsing Pythagoras theorem, we haveLN2= LM2+ MN2⇒ (25k)2= LM2+ (24k)2⇒ LM2= 625k2− 576k2⇒ LM2= 49k2⇒ LM = `sqrt(49k^2)`⇒ LM = 7kNow,sin θ = `["LM"]/["LN"] = [7k]/[25k] = 7/25`tan θ = `["LM"]/["NM"] = [7k]/[24k] = 7/24`Also,sin2θ = `( 7/25)^2 = 49/625`cos2θ = `(24/25)^2 = 576/625`
